resource.chars:
The existence of the new terms in the expression of the moon’s 
<s>Some time since<\s> coordinates occurred to me some time 
since, when I was engaged in thinking over a new 
method of treating the Lunar Theory, though I did 
not then perceive their important bearing on the 
secular equation <s>of the moon <\s>
My attention was first directed this subject while 
endeavouring to supply an omission in the Theory of 
the Moon given by Pontecoulant in his “Theorie Analytique”
In this <s>very<\s> valuable work, the author, following the 
example originally set by Sir J. Lubbock in his Tracts 
on the <s>Moon<\s> Lunar Theory obtains directly the expressions for the 
Moon’s coordinates in terms of the time, which are 
found in Plana’s Theory by means of the reversion 
of series. With respect to the secular acceleration 
of the mean motion, however, Pontecoulant unfortu-
nately adopts Plana’s result without examination.
On performing the calculation requisite to complete this 
part of the theory, I was surprised to find that the 
second term of the expression for the secular acceleration
